question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
What is the greatest prime factor of $12! + 14!$?  (Reminder: If $n$ is a positive integer, then $n!$ stands for the product $1\cdot 2\cdot 3\cdot \cdots \cdot (n-1)\cdot n$.)
inference:
$12! + 14! = 12!(1 + 14) = 12!(15) = 12! \times 3 \times 5$.
The prime factorization of 12! is $2^{10} \times 3^5 \times 5^2 \times 7 \times 11$.
So, $12! + 14! = (2^{10} \times 3^5 \times 5^2 \times 7 \times 11) \times 3 \times 5 = 2^{10} \times 3^6 \times 5^3 \times 7 \times 11$.
The greatest prime factor is 11.
Final Answer: $\boxed{11}$
ground_truth: Factor out $12!$ from both terms: $12!+14!=12!(1+13\cdot 14)=12!\cdot 183$.  Factor $183=3\cdot 61$.  Since $12!$ has no prime factors greater than 11, $\boxed{61}$ is the greatest prime factor of $12!+14!$.

inference:
$12! + 14! = 12! + 14 \times 13 \times 12! = 12!(1 + 14 \times 13) = 12!(1 + 182) = 12!(183)$.
$183 = 3 \times 61$.
$12! = 2^{10} \times 3^5 \times 5^2 \times 7 \times 11$.
So $12! + 14! = 12!(183) = 12!(3 \times 61) = 2^{10} \times 3^6 \times 5^2 \times 7 \times 11 \times 61$.
The greatest prime factor is 61.

Final Answer: $\boxed{61}$
ground_truth: Factor out $12!$ from both terms: $12!+14!=12!(1+13\cdot 14)=12!\cdot 183$.  Factor $183=3\cdot 61$.  Since $12!$ has no prime factors greater than 11, $\boxed{61}$ is the greatest prime factor of $12!+14!$.
